00063 UInt32::UInt32(const string &n) 
00064     : BaseType(n, dods_uint32_c, (xdrproc_t)XDR_UINT32)
00065 {
00066 }
00067 
00068 UInt32::UInt32(const UInt32 &copy_from) : BaseType(copy_from)
00069 {
00070     _buf = copy_from._buf;
00071 }
00072     
00073 BaseType *
00074 UInt32::ptr_duplicate()
00075 {
00076     return new UInt32(*this);
00077 }
00078 
00079 UInt32 &
00080 UInt32::operator=(const UInt32 &rhs)
00081 {
00082     if (this == &rhs)
00083     return *this;
00084 
00085     dynamic_cast<BaseType &>(*this) = rhs;
00086 
00087     _buf = rhs._buf;
00088 
00089     return *this;
00090 }
00091 
00092 unsigned int
00093 UInt32::width()
00094 {
00095     return sizeof(dods_uint32);
00096 }
00097 
00098 bool
00099 UInt32::serialize(const string &dataset, DDS &dds, XDR *sink, 
00100           bool ce_eval)
00101 {
00102     dds.timeout_on();
00103 
00104     if (!read_p())
00105     read(dataset);      // read() throws Error and InternalErr
00106 
00107     if (ce_eval && !dds.eval_selection(dataset))
00108     return true;
00109 
00110     dds.timeout_off();
00111 
00112     if (!XDR_UINT32(sink, &_buf))
00113     throw Error(
00114 "Network I/O Error. Could not send uint 32 data. This may be due to a\n\
00115 bug in DODS or a problem with the network connection.");
00116 
00117     return true;
00118 }
00119 
00120 bool
00121 UInt32::deserialize(XDR *source, DDS *, bool)
00122 {
00123     if (!XDR_UINT32(source, &_buf))
00124     throw Error(
00125 "Network I/O Error. Could not read uint 32 data. This may be due to a\n\
00126 bug in DODS or a problem with the network connection.");
00127 
00128     return false;
00129 }
00130 
00131 unsigned int
00132 UInt32::val2buf(void *val, bool)
00133 {
00134 
00135     // Jose Garcia
00136     // This method is public therefore and I believe it has being designed
00137     // to be use by read which must be implemented on the surrogated library,
00138     // thus if the pointer val is NULL, is an Internal Error. 
00139     if(!val)
00140     throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, 
00141               "The incoming pointer does not contain any data.");
00142 
00143     _buf = *(dods_uint32 *)val;
00144 
00145     return width();
00146 }
00147 
00148 unsigned int
00149 UInt32::buf2val(void **val)
00150 {
00151     // Jose Garcia
00152     // The same comment justifying throwing an Error in val2buf applies here.
00153     if (!val)
00154     throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, "NULL pointer.");
00155 
00156     if (!*val)
00157     *val = new dods_uint32;
00158 
00159     *(dods_uint32 *)*val =_buf;
00160 
00161     return width();
00162 }
00163 
00164 // Print BUF to stdout with its declaration. Intended mostly for debugging.
00165 
00166 void 
00167 UInt32::print_val(ostream &os, string space, bool print_decl_p)
00168 {
00169     if (print_decl_p) {
00170     print_decl(os, space, false);
00171     os << " = " << _buf << ";" << endl;
00172     }
00173     else 
00174     os << _buf;
00175 }
00176 
00177 void 
00178 UInt32::print_val(FILE *out, string space, bool print_decl_p)
00179 {
00180     if (print_decl_p) {
00181     print_decl(out, space, false);
00182     fprintf( out, " = %u;\n", (unsigned int)_buf ) ;
00183     }
00184     else 
00185     fprintf( out, "%u", (unsigned int)_buf ) ;
00186 }
00187 
00188 bool
00189 UInt32::ops(BaseType *b, int op, const string &dataset)
00190 {
00191     // Extract the Byte arg's value.
00192     if (!read_p() && !read(dataset)) {
00193     // Jose Garcia
00194     // Since the read method is virtual and implemented outside
00195     // libdap++ if we can not read the data that is the problem 
00196     // of the user or of whoever wrote the surrogate library
00197     // implemeting read therefore it is an internal error.
00198     throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, "This value was not read!");
00199     }
00200     
00201     // Extract the second arg's value.
00202     if (!b->read_p() && !b->read(dataset)) {
00203     // Jose Garcia
00204     // Since the read method is virtual and implemented outside
00205     // libdap++ if we can not read the data that is the problem 
00206     // of the user or of whoever wrote the surrogate library
00207     // implemeting read therefore it is an internal error.
00208     throw InternalErr(__FILE__, __LINE__, "This value was not read!");
00209     }
00210 
00211     switch (b->type()) {
00212       case dods_byte_c:
00213     return rops<dods_uint32, dods_byte, Cmp<dods_uint32, dods_byte> >
00214         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Byte *>(b)->_buf, op);
00215       case dods_int16_c:
00216     return rops<dods_uint32, dods_int16, USCmp<dods_uint32, dods_int16> >
00217         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Int16 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00218       case dods_uint16_c:
00219     return rops<dods_uint32, dods_uint16, Cmp<dods_uint32, dods_uint16> >
00220         (_buf, dynamic_cast<UInt16 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00221       case dods_int32_c:
00222     return rops<dods_uint32, dods_int32, USCmp<dods_uint32, dods_int32> >
00223         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Int32 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00224       case dods_uint32_c:
00225     return rops<dods_uint32, dods_uint32, Cmp<dods_uint32, dods_uint32> >
00226         (_buf, dynamic_cast<UInt32 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00227       case dods_float32_c:
00228     return rops<dods_uint32, dods_float32, Cmp<dods_uint32, dods_float32> >
00229         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Float32 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00230       case dods_float64_c:
00231     return rops<dods_uint32, dods_float64, Cmp<dods_uint32, dods_float64> >
00232         (_buf, dynamic_cast<Float64 *>(b)->_buf, op);
00233       default:
00234     return false;
00235     }
00236 }

00249 // depracated.
00250 // Added 'smart timeouts' to all the variable classes. This means that
00251 // the new server timeouts are active only for the data read and CE
00252 // evaluation. This went inthe BaseType::serialize() methods because it
00253 // needed to time both the read() calls and the dds::eval() calls.

00291 // Revision 1.18  2001/10/14 01:28:38  jimg

00294 // Revision 1.15.4.4  2001/10/02 17:01:52  jimg
00295 // Made the behavior of serialize and deserialize uniform. Both methods now
00296 // use Error exceptions to signal problems with network I/O and InternalErr
00297 // exceptions to signal other problems. The return codes, always true for
00298 // serialize and always false for deserialize, are now meaningless. However,
00299 // by always returning a code that means OK, old code should continue to work.
00300 //
00301 // Revision 1.17  2001/09/28 17:50:07  jimg
00302 // Merged with 3.2.7.
00303 //
00304 // Revision 1.15.4.3  2001/09/07 00:38:35  jimg
00305 // Sequence::deserialize(...) now reads all the sequence values at once.
00306 // Its call semantics are the same as the other classes' versions. Values
00307 // are stored in the Sequence object using a vector<BaseType *> for each
00308 // row (those are themselves held in a vector). Three new accessor methods
00309 // have been added to Sequence (row_value() and two versions of var_value()).
00310 // BaseType::deserialize(...) now always returns true. This matches with the
00311 // expectations of most client code (the seqeunce version returned false
00312 // when it was done reading, but all the calls for sequences must be changed
00313 // anyway). If an XDR error is found, deserialize throws InternalErr.
00314 //
00315 // Revision 1.16  2001/08/24 17:46:22  jimg
00316 // Resolved conflicts from the merge of release 3.2.6
00317 //
00318 // Revision 1.15.4.2  2001/08/18 00:13:40  jimg
00319 // Removed WIN32 compile guards from using statements.
00320 //
00321 // Revision 1.15.4.1  2001/07/28 01:10:42  jimg
00322 // Some of the numeric type classes did not have copy ctors or operator=.
00323 // I added those where they were needed.
00324 // In every place where delete (or delete []) was called, I set the pointer
00325 // just deleted to zero. Thus if for some reason delete is called again
00326 // before new memory is allocated there won't be a mysterious crash. This is
00327 // just good form when using delete.
00328 // I added calls to www2id and id2www where appropriate. The DAP now handles
00329 // making sure that names are escaped and unescaped as needed. Connect is
00330 // set to handle CEs that contain names as they are in the dataset (see the
00331 // comments/Log there). Servers should not handle escaping or unescaping
00332 // characters on their own.
00333 //
00334 // Revision 1.15  2000/10/06 01:26:05  jimg
00335 // Changed the way serialize() calls read(). The status from read() is
00336 // returned by the Structure and Sequence serialize() methods; ignored by
00337 // all others. Any exceptions thrown by read() are caught and discarded.
00338 // serialize() returns false if read() throws an exception. This should
00339 // be fixed once all the servers build using the new read() definition.
00340 //
00341 // Revision 1.14  2000/09/22 02:17:21  jimg

00344 // wrapped headers included in other headers in those guard symbols (to cut

00346 //
00347 // Revision 1.13  2000/09/21 16:22:09  jimg
00348 // Merged changes from Jose Garcia that add exceptions to the software.
00349 // Many methods that returned error codes now throw exectptions. There are
00350 // two classes which are thrown by the software, Error and InternalErr.
00351 // InternalErr is used to report errors within the library or errors using
00352 // the library. Error is used to reprot all other errors. Since InternalErr
00353 // is a subclass of Error, programs need only to catch Error.
00354 //
